questions.text: Which of the following findings is characteristic of auditory neuropathy spectrum disorder (ANSD)?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal otoacoustic emissions with abnormal auditory brainstem responses

options.label: B
options.text: Abnormal otoacoustic emissions with normal auditory brainstem responses

options.label: C
options.text: Absent otoacoustic emissions with normal auditory brainstem responses

options.label: D
options.text: Absent both otoacoustic emissions and auditory brainstem responses

questions.correct_answer: A. Normal otoacoustic emissions with abnormal auditory brainstem responses
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Normal otoacoustic emissions with abnormal auditory brainstem responses

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic finding of auditory neuropathy spectrum disorder (ANSD) is normal otoacoustic emissions with abnormal auditory brainstem responses . This reflects a problem in the auditory nerve with a normally functioning cochlea.
  • ➤ normal otoacoustic emissions with abnormal auditory brainstem responses

questions.text: The first synapse in the central auditory pathway, after sound is transduced in the cochlea, occurs at which of the following nuclei?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cochlear nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first synapse in the central auditory pathway, after sound is transduced in the cochlea, occurs at the cochlear nucleus .
  • ➤ cochlear nucleus

questions.text: Distortion-product otoacoustic emissions (DPOAEs) are generated by which of the following structures in the ear?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Outer hair cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Distortion-product otoacoustic emissions (DPOAEs) are generated by the outer hair cells in the cochlea. These emissions are used as an indicator of normal cochlear function.
  • ➤ outer hair cells

questions.text: In a BERA test, which wave corresponds to the activity of the inferior colliculus?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Option A – Wave I : Represents the auditory nerve , not the brainstem or midbrain structures. Option B – Wave III : Generated by the cochlear nucleus , not the inferior colliculus. Option D – Wave VII : Not used clinically ; the ABR test primarily interprets waves I through V. Wave VII is not consistently seen or clinically significant.
  • • Option A – Wave I : Represents the auditory nerve , not the brainstem or midbrain structures.
  • • Option A – Wave I
  • • auditory nerve
  • • Option B – Wave III : Generated by the cochlear nucleus , not the inferior colliculus.
  • • Option B – Wave III
  • • cochlear nucleus
  • • Option D – Wave VII : Not used clinically ; the ABR test primarily interprets waves I through V. Wave VII is not consistently seen or clinically significant.
  • • Option D – Wave VII
  • • Not used clinically

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Wave V in BERA corresponds to activity in the inferior colliculus and is the most reliable wave for estimating auditory thresholds.
  • ➤ Wave V in BERA corresponds to activity in the inferior colliculus and is the most reliable wave for estimating auditory thresholds.

questions.text: Grade III Sade retraction of pars tensa refers to which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Retracted to the level of the annulus

options.label: B
options.text: Retraction touching the incus or stapes

questions.correct_answer: C. Retraction adherent to the promontory
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Retraction adherent to the promontory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grade III Sade retraction of the pars tensa refers to the tympanic membrane being adherent to the promontory in the middle ear. This stage reflects a significant retraction of the tympanic membrane.
  • ➤ adherent to the promontory

questions.text: Which type of hearing loss is characterized by a significant air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds on pure-tone audiometry?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conductive hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conductive hearing loss is characterized by a significant air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds on pure-tone audiometry, indicating a problem in the outer or middle ear but normal function of the cochlea and auditory nerve.
  • ➤ significant air-bone gap
  • ➤ normal bone conduction thresholds

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common intracranial complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Meningitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meningitis is the most common intracranial complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) , characterized by the spread of infection to the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord.
  • ➤ Meningitis
  • ➤ chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)

questions.text: In Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty, Type II refers to which surgical procedure?
questions.correct_answer: B. Graft placed on the incus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Graft placed on the incus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Type II tympanoplasty , the graft is placed on the incus to restore sound transmission when the malleus is absent or damaged.
  • ➤ Type II tympanoplasty
  • ➤ incus

questions.text: In BPPV, which of the following canals is most commonly affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posterior semicircular canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In BPPV , the posterior semicircular canal is most commonly affected due to its anatomical orientation, which makes it more susceptible to the dislodgment and accumulation of otoliths.
  • ➤ BPPV
  • ➤ posterior semicircular canal

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate management of pinna hematoma to prevent complications such as cauliflower ear?

options.label: C
options.text: Incision and drainage with compression dressing

questions.correct_answer: C. Incision and drainage with compression dressing
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage with compression dressing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate management of pinna hematoma to prevent complications such as cauliflower ear is incision and drainage with a compression dressing . This relieves pressure on the cartilage, preventing necrosis and deformation.
  • ➤ pinna hematoma
  • ➤ cauliflower ear
  • ➤ incision and drainage with a compression dressing

questions.text: The natural drainage of the maxillary sinus is via the:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Middle meatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus , along with the frontal sinus and anterior ethmoidal air cells.
  • ➤ maxillary sinus
  • ➤ middle meatus

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic histopathological feature of inverted papilloma?
questions.correct_answer: B. Inward growth of the epithelium
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inward growth of the epithelium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic histopathological feature of inverted papilloma is the inward growth of the epithelium into the underlying stroma, distinguishing it from other neoplastic conditions that exhibit outward growth.
  • ➤ inverted papilloma
  • ➤ inward growth of the epithelium

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is the major contributor to Kiesselbach’s plexus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sphenopalatine artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sphenopalatine artery is the major contributor to Kiesselbach’s plexus , which is a common site for anterior epistaxis.
  • ➤ sphenopalatine artery
  • ➤ Kiesselbach’s plexus

questions.text: Which X-ray view is best for visualizing the frontal sinuses?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Caldwell view

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Caldwell view is the best X-ray view for visualizing the frontal sinuses , while other views are better suited for specific sinuses, such as the Waters view for maxillary sinuses and the submentovertex view for sphenoid sinuses.
  • ➤ Caldwell view
  • ➤ frontal sinuses

questions.text: Which muscle forms the bulk of the posterior pharyngeal wall and is responsible for constricting the pharynx during swallowing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Superior constrictor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The superior constrictor muscle forms the bulk of the posterior pharyngeal wall and is primarily responsible for constricting the pharynx during swallowing, preventing food from entering the nasopharynx and aiding in the passage of the food bolus into the esophagus.
  • ➤ superior constrictor

questions.text: Adenoid hypertrophy primarily obstructs which part of the airway?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nasopharynx

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoid hypertrophy primarily obstructs the nasopharynx , leading to breathing difficulties and other related symptoms due to the blockage of airflow through the upper part of the airway.
  • ➤ Adenoid hypertrophy
  • ➤ nasopharynx

questions.text: Which nerve supplies motor innervation to all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies motor innervation to all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid , which is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve .
  • ➤ recurrent laryngeal nerve
  • ➤ except the cricothyroid
  • ➤ external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following methods of post-laryngectomy voice rehabilitation involves the placement of a one-way valve that allows air to enter the esophagus for speech production?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tracheoesophageal puncture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheoesophageal puncture (TEP) involves the placement of a one-way valve that allows air to enter the esophagus for speech production, providing a more natural form of voice rehabilitation after a laryngectomy.
  • ➤ Tracheoesophageal puncture (TEP)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with hearing loss that developed shortly after her first pregnancy. Her audiometry report is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Otosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis is characterized by conductive hearing loss, a significant air-bone gap, and Carhart’s notch at 2000 Hz on the audiogram. It commonly affects women, especially after pregnancy, due to hormonal influences on bone metabolism. The treatment of choice is stapedotomy .
  • ➤ Otosclerosis
  • ➤ stapedotomy

questions.text: Following drug damages the area shown as * in the below image of organ of corti:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cisplatin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cisplatin is a chemotherapeutic agent that damages the outer hair cells of the organ of Corti, leading to hearing loss. This ototoxicity primarily affects high-frequency hearing and can be irreversible.
  • ➤ Cisplatin
  • ➤ outer hair cells

questions.text: What does the below audiogram suggest?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Noise induced hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A dip at 4000 Hz on an audiogram is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) , which is usually bilateral due to equal exposure to loud sounds in both ears.
  • ➤ 4000 Hz
  • ➤ noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL)

questions.text: Which is true regarding the blue line shown in the below picture:

options.label: A
options.text: It is called as Frankfurt line

options.label: B
options.text: Tumors above this line have good prognosis

options.label: C
options.text: Tumors below this line have bad prognosis

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are false

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ongren's line helps determine the prognosis of maxillary sinus tumors. Tumors above the line tend to have a worse prognosis due to their proximity to vital structures, while those below have a better prognosis .
  • ➤ Ongren's line
  • ➤ above
  • ➤ worse prognosis
  • ➤ below
  • ➤ better prognosis

questions.text: The given image is of a patient in which mastoidectomy is done. Identify the posterior semicircular canal:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior semicircular canal is located at B in the image and is identified as part of the inner ear's balance system.
  • ➤ posterior semicircular canal
  • ➤ B

questions.text: Which of the following is a branch of the external carotid artery in Kiesselbach's plexus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Spheno palatine artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sphenopalatine artery , a branch of the external carotid artery , is a key contributor to the blood supply of Kiesselbach's plexus . Other contributors to this vascular plexus include branches from both the internal and external carotid arteries.
  • ➤ sphenopalatine artery
  • ➤ external carotid artery
  • ➤ Kiesselbach's plexus

questions.text: While performing a caloric test, what type of nystagmus would you expect on warm water irrigation?

options.label: A
options.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side

options.label: B
options.text: Vertical nystagmus towards the same side

options.label: C
options.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

options.label: D
options.text: Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.correct_answer: A. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the caloric test, warm water irrigation induces horizontal nystagmus towards the same side (remembered by the mnemonic COWS ).
  • ➤ warm water
  • ➤ horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
  • ➤ COWS

questions.text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has Minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stage IIA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Radkowski Stage IIA of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, the tumor extends beyond the nasopharynx into the pterygopalatine fossa with minimal involvement, distinguishing it from more advanced stages where the tumor completely fills or extends further laterally.
  • ➤ Radkowski Stage IIA
  • ➤ pterygopalatine fossa

questions.text: Sudden fall due to sudden onset of giddiness but no loss of consciousness is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Meniere disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumarkin's otolithic crisis occurs in Meniere disease and causes sudden falls due to vertigo but without loss of consciousness, differentiating it from other causes of balance disorders or central vertigo.
  • ➤ Tumarkin's otolithic crisis
  • ➤ Meniere disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not an etiological factor for head and neck malignancies?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin D deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary etiological factors for head and neck malignancies include viral infections (EBV and HPV), tobacco , alcohol , and betel nut chewing . Vitamin D deficiency is not currently considered a major risk factor for these cancers.
  • ➤ head and neck malignancies
  • ➤ viral infections
  • ➤ tobacco
  • ➤ alcohol
  • ➤ betel nut chewing
  • ➤ Vitamin D deficiency

questions.text: A patient undergoes surgery of the lateral part of the base of the skull. Postoperatively, the patient presents with aspiration but does not have a change in voice. Which of the following is the reason?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Superior laryngeal nerve injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve causes loss of sensation above the vocal cords , leading to aspiration without affecting the voice, as the vocal cords remain functional.
  • ➤ internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
  • ➤ loss of sensation above the vocal cords
  • ➤ aspiration

questions.text: A patient underwent total laryngectomy for laryngeal cancer. Identify the modality of voice production in this patient shown in the image given below
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Electro-larynx

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An electrolarynx is an external handheld device that produces vibrations for voice production in patients who have undergone a total laryngectomy, as shown in the image.
  • ➤ electrolarynx

questions.text: Anterior most air cells of anterior ethmoidal sinus are
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Agger Nasi cells are the anterior-most ethmoidal air cells and are important in the drainage of the frontal sinuses. They are often involved in sinus-related pathologies and are a key focus during functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS).
  • ➤ Agger Nasi cells

questions.text: A patient complaining of vertigo without hearing loss has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon performs a diagnostic maneuver and cautiously performs a therapeutic maneuver. What is the therapeutic maneuver?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epley's maneuver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the treatment of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) , the Epley's maneuver is the therapeutic maneuver used to reposition displaced otoliths. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is the diagnostic test used to confirm BPPV.
  • ➤ benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)
  • ➤ Epley's maneuver
  • ➤ Dix-Hallpike maneuver

questions.text: Identify the retractor shown in the below image
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Joll's retractor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Joll's retractor is specifically used in thyroid surgery to retract the skin and soft tissue for better visualization and access to the thyroid gland.
  • ➤ Joll's retractor

questions.text: A senior medical professional at the hospital is conducting the clinical examination depicted in the provided image. Which of the subsequent anatomical structures will be visible to him?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arytenoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During indirect laryngoscopy , structures such as the arytenoids and vocal cords are visualized, whereas structures in the nasopharynx , like the adenoids and torus tubarius , are not.
  • ➤ indirect laryngoscopy
  • ➤ arytenoids
  • ➤ nasopharynx
  • ➤ adenoids
  • ➤ torus tubarius

questions.text: Given below is the endoscopic view of the left nasal cavity. Identify the marked structure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Middle turbinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The middle turbinate is a critical structure in the nasal cavity, often visualized during endoscopic examination.
  • ➤ middle turbinate

questions.text: All of the following are minor diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Positive fungal stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In allergic fungal sinusitis (AFS) , positive fungal stain is a major diagnostic criterion because it provides rapid confirmation of fungal involvement, while fungal culture is a minor criterion due to the delayed time for results.
  • ➤ allergic fungal sinusitis (AFS)
  • ➤ positive fungal stain
  • ➤ major diagnostic criterion
  • ➤ fungal culture
  • ➤ minor criterion

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Right hypoactive labyrinth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of vertigo with horizontal nystagmus, the slow phase of the nystagmus indicates the side of the vestibular lesion or hypofunction. The fast phase shows the direction of the nystagmus, which is the opposite of the lesion side. For example, right hypoactive labyrinth leads to slow-phase nystagmus to the right and fast-phase nystagmus to the left .
  • ➤ slow phase
  • ➤ fast phase
  • ➤ opposite
  • ➤ right hypoactive labyrinth
  • ➤ slow-phase nystagmus to the right
  • ➤ fast-phase nystagmus to the left

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS for failed conservative management 5 years ago. A DNE done now shows blocked ostia. What is the next best step in management? (FESS- Functional endoscopic sinus surgery.)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Repeat surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient presents with blocked sinus ostia following prior FESS, repeat surgery is the best approach to restore proper sinus drainage and ventilation. Conservative treatments are ineffective when there is a physical obstruction of the sinus drainage pathways.
  • ➤ repeat surgery

questions.text: A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her tympanogram findings are given below. Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient.

options.label: A
options.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

options.label: B
options.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

options.label: C
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

options.label: D
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of conductive hearing loss , Rinne's test is negative on the affected side, and Weber's test lateralizes to the affected side.
  • ➤ conductive hearing loss
  • ➤ Rinne's test
  • ➤ Weber's test

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the clinic due to difficulty hearing conversations over the past year. He reports that he often has trouble hearing people unless they speak loudly and close to him. The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypertension and long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus. He does not have ear pain, discharge, or a history of ear infections. Otoscopic examination reveals no abnormalities. Pure-tone audiometry shows an average threshold of 55 dB HL across 500, 1000, and 2000 Hz in both ears. Which of the following is the correct classification of this patient’s hearing impairment according to the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Moderate impairment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A pure-tone average hearing threshold of 55 dB is classified as moderate hearing impairment according to the WHO criteria.
  • ➤ 55 dB
  • ➤ moderate hearing impairment

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to concerns about his hearing. The child has had difficulty hearing conversations and responding to questions over the past two months. His parents also note that he seems distracted at school and frequently turns up the volume on the television. The patient had multiple episodes of otitis media in the past year but has not had any fever or ear pain recently. Otoscopic examination shows a retracted tympanic membrane with visible air-fluid levels. Tympanometry reveals a type B (flat) curve bilaterally. Audiometry confirms a bilateral conductive hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism causing his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperplasia of the adenoid tissues causing Eustachian tube obstruction

options.label: B
options.text: Increased mucous secretion from hypertrophied middle ear mucosa

options.label: C
options.text: Biofilm formation by resistant organisms in the middle ear cavity

options.label: D
options.text: Defective ciliary function in the Eustachian tube mucosa

questions.correct_answer: A. Hyperplasia of the adenoid tissues causing Eustachian tube obstruction
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hyperplasia of the adenoid tissues causing Eustachian tube obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otitis media with effusion is commonly caused by Eustachian tube dysfunction due to adenoid hypertrophy in children. It presents with conductive hearing loss, a flat tympanogram (type B), and a history of recurrent ear infections. Management often includes addressing the underlying adenoid hypertrophy if conservative treatments fail.
  • ➤ Otitis media with effusion
  • ➤ Eustachian tube dysfunction
  • ➤ adenoid hypertrophy

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and a sensation of fullness in her left ear for the past six months. Each episode lasts several hours, during which she also experiences tinnitus in the affected ear. She denies headaches, visual disturbances, or recent upper respiratory infections. Otoscopic examination is unremarkable, and neurological examination shows no focal deficits. Audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss in the lower frequencies of the left ear. Based on her clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism causing her symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased production of endolymph within scala tympani

options.label: B
options.text: Defective reabsorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac

options.label: C
options.text: Ischemia of the vestibular and cochlear structures due to vasospasm

options.label: D
options.text: Autoimmune-mediated destruction of the cochlear hair cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Defective reabsorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Defective reabsorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ménière’s disease is primarily caused by endolymphatic hydrops , which results from defective reabsorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac . This fluid imbalance causes episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. The lower frequencies are typically affected in the early stages of the disease.
  • ➤ Ménière’s disease
  • ➤ endolymphatic hydrops
  • ➤ defective reabsorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the audiology clinic for evaluation of her hearing. She has no significant past medical history and denies any hearing loss or tinnitus. However, she works in a noisy factory environment and is concerned about potential noise-induced hearing loss. Her audiogram is normal. Otoacoustic emission (OAE) testing shows absent emissions in both ears. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the absence of OAEs in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Inner hair cell dysfunction causing impaired auditory nerve transmission

options.label: B
options.text: Outer hair cell damage leading to loss of cochlear amplification

options.label: C
options.text: Middle ear effusion dampening the transmission of sound to the cochlea

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive hearing loss due to ossicular chain dysfunction

questions.correct_answer: B. Outer hair cell damage leading to loss of cochlear amplification
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Outer hair cell damage leading to loss of cochlear amplification

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients exposed to chronic loud noise, outer hair cell damage can occur even if pure-tone audiometry is normal. Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are a sensitive test for detecting early damage to outer hair cells. Noise-induced hearing loss often starts with damage to these cells, which are essential for cochlear amplification, before progressing to detectable changes on an audiogram.
  • ➤ outer hair cell damage
  • ➤ Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs)
  • ➤ Noise-induced hearing loss

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss in his left ear, associated with occasional imbalance. His audiogram shows a moderate sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear, and speech discrimination scores are significantly worse in the left ear compared to the right. Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) is performed, which reveals a prolonged latency of Wave V on the left side and an increased interpeak latency between Waves I and V. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vestibular schwannoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma) often presents with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss , poorer speech discrimination , and sometimes imbalance . BERA is a useful diagnostic tool, where prolonged latency of Wave V and increased interpeak latency between Waves I and V suggest a retrocochlear lesion , such as vestibular schwannoma.
  • ➤ Vestibular schwannoma
  • ➤ progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss
  • ➤ poorer speech discrimination
  • ➤ imbalance
  • ➤ prolonged latency of Wave V
  • ➤ increased interpeak latency
  • ➤ retrocochlear lesion

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent ear infections and progressive hearing loss in the right ear. Otoscopic examination reveals marked retraction of the pars tensa, which is adherent to the promontory, and the pars flaccida is deeply retracted with exposure of the lateral process of the malleus and early erosion of the scutum. Audiometry shows mild conductive hearing loss. Which of the following best describes the grading of both pars tensa and pars flaccida retractions in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Sade grade 3 pars tensa retraction, Tos Type I pars flaccida retraction

options.label: B
options.text: Sade grade 2 pars tensa retraction, Tos Type II pars flaccida retraction

options.label: C
options.text: Sade grade 3 pars tensa retraction, Tos Type IV pars flaccida retraction

options.label: D
options.text: Sade grade 5 pars tensa retraction, Tos Type IV pars flaccida retraction

questions.correct_answer: C. Sade grade 3 pars tensa retraction, Tos Type IV pars flaccida retraction
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sade grade 3 pars tensa retraction, Tos Type IV pars flaccida retraction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sade grading system is used to classify retractions of the pars tensa , and the Tos classification is used for the pars flaccida . In this case:
  • ➤ Sade grading
  • ➤ pars tensa
  • ➤ Tos classification
  • ➤ pars flaccida
  • ➤ Sade grade 3 for pars tensa indicates retraction touching the promontory. Tos Type IV for pars flaccida refers to deep retraction with erosion of the scutum.
  • ➤ Sade grade 3 for pars tensa indicates retraction touching the promontory.
  • ➤ Sade grade 3
  • ➤ Tos Type IV for pars flaccida refers to deep retraction with erosion of the scutum.
  • ➤ Tos Type IV

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media in his left ear. He underwent tympanoplasty 3 months ago and reports improved hearing. Otoscopic examination shows a well-healed graft over the tympanic membrane. Audiometry reveals a reduction in the air-bone gap, but his hearing is still mildly reduced. The surgical report states that the graft was placed directly on the stapes as the incus and malleus were eroded. Which of the following Wullstein tympanoplasty types was most likely performed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type III Tympanoplasty is performed when both the malleus and incus are absent, and the graft is placed directly on the stapes to restore hearing. This is the most appropriate classification when the stapes is intact and functional.
  • ➤ Type III Tympanoplasty

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with chronic ear discharge and hearing loss in the right ear for the past two years. His past medical history includes multiple surgeries for cholesteatoma, but his ear discharge persists. Audiometry shows moderate conductive hearing loss in the right ear. Despite trialing air-conduction hearing aids, he complains of persistent feedback and discomfort. Examination shows a chronically inflamed ear canal, with no evidence of active infection. Given his condition, the decision is made to proceed with a bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA). Which of the following is the most important factor in determining this patient’s candidacy for BAHA?

options.label: C
options.text: Ability to undergo osseointegration of the titanium implant

questions.correct_answer: C. Ability to undergo osseointegration of the titanium implant
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ability to undergo osseointegration of the titanium implant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osseointegration is the most important factor in determining the success of a bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA) as it ensures that the titanium implant integrates securely with the bone to support the external hearing device.
  • ➤ Osseointegration

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with complaints of sneezing, nasal congestion, and watery rhinorrhea for the past few months. These symptoms worsen during the spring season. She has no history of asthma or nasal polyps. Physical examination reveals pale, boggy nasal mucosa with clear nasal discharge. Which of the following is the most likely underlying immune mechanism involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IgE-mediated hypersensitivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allergic rhinitis is caused by IgE-mediated hypersensitivity (Type I), which involves mast cell degranulation upon exposure to allergens, leading to the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators that cause typical allergic symptoms.
  • ➤ IgE-mediated hypersensitivity

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from Tamil Nadu presents with a history of nasal obstruction and intermittent epistaxis for the past six months. On examination, a pinkish, polypoidal mass is noted in the nasal cavity, which bleeds easily on touch. Biopsy reveals sporangia filled with spores. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidium seeberi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis , caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi , presents as a bleeding, polypoidal mass in the nasal cavity with histological findings of sporangia filled with spores . It is endemic in regions like Tamil Nadu, particularly among individuals exposed to contaminated water sources.
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis
  • ➤ Rhinosporidium seeberi
  • ➤ bleeding, polypoidal mass
  • ➤ sporangia filled with spores

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with complaints of an altered sense of smell for the past six months. He describes the smell of food as unpleasant and occasionally foul. He has a history of a viral upper respiratory infection a few months ago. There is no history of trauma or nasal polyps. On examination, the nasal mucosa is normal. Neurological examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

options.label: B
options.text: Misguided regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers

options.label: C
options.text: Obstruction of the olfactory region by nasal polyps

options.label: D
options.text: Injury to the olfactory bulb due to trauma

questions.correct_answer: B. Misguided regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Misguided regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parosmia is commonly caused by misguided regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers following nerve damage due to viral infections, leading to the misinterpretation of smells. This is a known post-viral olfactory dysfunction where patients perceive normal smells as unpleasant.
  • ➤ Parosmia
  • ➤ misguided regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers

questions.text: Identify the structure in the below picture which does not have any muscular attachment:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The incus is the only ossicle in the middle ear that does not have a muscular attachment. This unique characteristic distinguishes it from the malleus and stapes, which have attachments to the tensor tympani and stapedius muscles, respectively.

questions.text: Which numbered structure is not a boundary of facial recess in the given image showing posterior tympanotomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial recess is bordered by the vertical portion of the facial nerve (medial), chorda tympani nerve (lateral), and incudal fossa (superior).

questions.text: Identify the types of audiograms sequentially from left to right:

options.label: A
options.text: Normal, sensorineural loss, conductive loss, mixed loss

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural loss, normal, conductive loss, mixed loss

options.label: C
options.text: Normal, conductive loss, sensorineural loss, mixed loss

options.label: D
options.text: Mixed loss, sensorineural loss, normal, conductive loss

questions.correct_answer: C. Normal, conductive loss, sensorineural loss, mixed loss
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Normal, conductive loss, sensorineural loss, mixed loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Audiograms help differentiate between normal hearing, conductive loss, sensorineural loss, and mixed loss by analyzing air conduction and bone conduction thresholds and identifying air-bone gaps.
  • ➤ Audiograms help differentiate between normal hearing, conductive loss, sensorineural loss, and mixed loss by analyzing air conduction and bone conduction thresholds and identifying air-bone gaps.

questions.text: Identify in sequence from left to right

options.label: A
options.text: OME, MYRINGITIS BULLOSA, CSOM, GLOMUS, ASOM

options.label: B
options.text: MYRINGITIS BULLOSA, CSOM, OME, ASOM, GLOMUS

options.label: C
options.text: CSOM, OME, ASOM, MYRINGITIS BULLOSA, GLOMUS

questions.correct_answer: A. OME, MYRINGITIS BULLOSA, CSOM, GLOMUS, ASOM
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) OME, MYRINGITIS BULLOSA, CSOM, GLOMUS, ASOM

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • First Image (OME) : This image shows air-fluid levels behind the tympanic membrane, characteristic of Otitis Media with Effusion (OME) . The fluid trapped behind the eardrum often causes a bulging appearance and hearing loss without infection. Second Image (Myringitis Bullosa) : This shows multiple bullae on the surface of the tympanic membrane, which is indicative of Myringitis Bullosa , a viral infection of the tympanic membrane leading to blister formation. Third Image (CSOM) : The presence of a perforation in the tympanic membrane with visible discharge is consistent with Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) . Fourth Image (Glomus) : This image shows a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane, often referred to as the "rising sun" sign. This is characteristic of a Glomus tumor , a vascular tumor in the middle ear. Fifth Image (ASOM) : The tympanic membrane is red and bulging, which is indicative of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) in its suppurative stage.
  • • First Image (OME) : This image shows air-fluid levels behind the tympanic membrane, characteristic of Otitis Media with Effusion (OME) . The fluid trapped behind the eardrum often causes a bulging appearance and hearing loss without infection.
  • • First Image (OME)
  • • Otitis Media with Effusion (OME)
  • • Second Image (Myringitis Bullosa) : This shows multiple bullae on the surface of the tympanic membrane, which is indicative of Myringitis Bullosa , a viral infection of the tympanic membrane leading to blister formation.
  • • Second Image (Myringitis Bullosa)
  • • Myringitis Bullosa
  • • Third Image (CSOM) : The presence of a perforation in the tympanic membrane with visible discharge is consistent with Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) .
  • • Third Image (CSOM)
  • • Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM)
  • • Fourth Image (Glomus) : This image shows a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane, often referred to as the "rising sun" sign. This is characteristic of a Glomus tumor , a vascular tumor in the middle ear.
  • • Fourth Image (Glomus)
  • • Glomus tumor
  • • Fifth Image (ASOM) : The tympanic membrane is red and bulging, which is indicative of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) in its suppurative stage.
  • • Fifth Image (ASOM)
  • • Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Based on their sequence from left to right images:
  • ➤ 1. OME
  • ➤ 2. Myringitis bullosa
  • ➤ 3. CSOM
  • ➤ 4. Glomus
  • ➤ 5. ASOM

questions.text: A patient with post traumatic facial nerve palsy has presented with absent taste sensation on anterior 2/3rd part of his tongue. His stapedial reflex was checked and it was absent. Schirmer’s test for lacrimation was done and it was negative .i.e., lacrimation was normal. Most probable site of facial nerve lesion could be at

options.label: A
options.text: Translabyrinthine portion (the portion of facial nerve lying at the level of inner ear)

options.label: B
options.text: Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear

options.label: C
options.text: Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear

options.label: D
options.text: In the parotid substance where it divides into its 5 terminal branches

questions.correct_answer: B. Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lesions in different segments of the facial nerve produce distinct clinical manifestations based on which branches are affected. A lesion in the horizontal portion of the facial nerve (post-geniculate) results in loss of taste in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and absence of stapedial reflex , but lacrimation remains intact .
  • ➤ horizontal portion of the facial nerve
  • ➤ loss of taste
  • ➤ absence of stapedial reflex
  • ➤ lacrimation remains intact

questions.text: Laryngeal paralysis – true statement

options.label: A
options.text: In unilateral vocal cord palsy, phonation is more affected than respiration

options.label: B
options.text: In bilateral vocal cord palsy, respiration is more affected than phonation

options.label: C
options.text: Arytenoidectomy is done in bilateral vocal cord palsy

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngeal paralysis can affect both phonation and respiration, but the severity depends on whether the paralysis is unilateral or bilateral. In unilateral palsy, phonation is more affected , while in bilateral palsy, respiration is more severely compromised , requiring procedures like arytenoidectomy to alleviate the breathing difficulty.
  • ➤ phonation is more affected
  • ➤ respiration is more severely compromised

questions.text: Regarding the drainage of the paranasal sinuses, find the true statement

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior ethmoid drains into middle meatus

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and C are true

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior ethmoid drains into middle meatus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior ethmoid drains into middle meatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior ethmoid, maxillary, and frontal sinuses drain into the middle meatus , while the sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess . The nasolacrimal duct is the only structure that drains into the inferior meatus .
  • ➤ middle meatus
  • ➤ sphenoethmoidal recess
  • ➤ nasolacrimal duct
  • ➤ inferior meatus

questions.text: A 30 year old female came with complaints of hardness of hearing which was gradually progressive. On examination, tympanic membrane was intact but slight haziness was noticed. Rinne was negative on right side and weber lateralised to the right ear. A pure tone audiometry was advised. Which of the following audiogram belongs to the above patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In conductive hearing loss, bone conduction thresholds are typically normal, while air conduction thresholds are impaired, leading to an air-bone gap on audiometry. The negative Rinne's test and Weber's test lateralizing to the affected ear help confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: After a road traﬃc accident, a patient presented with watery discharge from l nostril that cannot be sniﬀed back. Find the true statement regarding the condition.

options.label: A
options.text: Beta 2 transferrin present in the discharge is important in diagnosing the condition

options.label: B
options.text: Handkerchief will be stiﬀened by this discharge

options.label: C
options.text: A central yellowish spot surrounded by a red halo can be seen when a drop of discharge is kept on a paper

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and C are true

questions.correct_answer: A. Beta 2 transferrin present in the discharge is important in diagnosing the condition
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Beta 2 transferrin present in the discharge is important in diagnosing the condition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of beta-2 transferrin in nasal discharge is the key diagnostic marker for CSF rhinorrhea , commonly seen after head trauma. The correct description of the halo sign is a central red spot surrounded by a yellow halo.
  • ➤ beta-2 transferrin
  • ➤ CSF rhinorrhea
  • ➤ halo sign

questions.text: In internal auditory canal, which nerve lies posteroinferiorly

options.label: B
options.text: Nerve concerned with horizontal linear acceleration

options.label: C
options.text: Nerve concerned with vertical linear acceleration

questions.correct_answer: C. Nerve concerned with vertical linear acceleration
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nerve concerned with vertical linear acceleration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the internal auditory canal, the inferior vestibular nerve , which is responsible for sensing vertical linear acceleration through the saccule , lies in the posteroinferior quadrant.
  • ➤ inferior vestibular nerve
  • ➤ vertical linear acceleration
  • ➤ saccule
  • ➤ posteroinferior

questions.text: In fitzgerald-hallpike bithermal caloric test
questions.correct_answer: A. Horizontal canal is oriented vertically
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Horizontal canal is oriented vertically

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the Fitzgerald-Hallpike caloric test , the horizontal canal is oriented vertically by tilting the patient's head 30 degrees forward in the supine position to stimulate the canal effectively.
  • ➤ Fitzgerald-Hallpike caloric test
  • ➤ horizontal canal

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A3, B4, C1, D2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Water view is used to assess the maxillary sinuses . The Basal view (submentovertex) is used for the sphenoid sinus . The Caldwell view is used for the frontal sinuses . The Rhese view is associated with the ethmoid sinuses .
  • ➤ The Water view is used to assess the maxillary sinuses .
  • ➤ Water view
  • ➤ maxillary sinuses
  • ➤ The Basal view (submentovertex) is used for the sphenoid sinus .
  • ➤ Basal view
  • ➤ sphenoid sinus
  • ➤ The Caldwell view is used for the frontal sinuses .
  • ➤ Caldwell view
  • ➤ frontal sinuses
  • ➤ The Rhese view is associated with the ethmoid sinuses .
  • ➤ Rhese view
  • ➤ ethmoid sinuses

questions.text: Identify the location of foreign body in this x ray
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An understanding of the basic anatomy of the neck structures, including the hyoid bone, epiglottis, thyroid cartilage, and cricoid cartilage, is crucial in interpreting neck X-rays to differentiate between normal structures and pathological findings such as foreign bodies.

questions.text: In BPPV

options.label: A
options.text: Otoconia from utricle enter semicircular canal and irritate macula

options.label: B
options.text: Epley maneuvre is diagnostic and dix-hallpike is therapeutic

options.label: C
options.text: Only vertigo is the presenting complaint

options.label: D
options.text: All the above statements are false

questions.correct_answer: C. Only vertigo is the presenting complaint
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Only vertigo is the presenting complaint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In BPPV, only vertigo occurs as the presenting complaint, and the dislodged otoconia irritate the crista ampullaris in the semicircular canals, not the macula. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is diagnostic, and the Epley maneuver is therapeutic.

questions.text: A patient presented with right sided hardness of hearing. Her tuning fork tests revealed that rinne is negative on right side, positive on left side and weber lateralised towards left. What could be the possible inference from this ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right severe SNHL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) , the Rinne test can produce a false negative result due to contralateral bone conduction. Additionally, Weber lateralizes to the unaffected ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the affected ear in conductive hearing loss.
  • ➤ severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
  • ➤ Rinne test
  • ➤ false negative
  • ➤ Weber lateralizes
  • ➤ unaffected ear

questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Heimlich maneuver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Heimlich maneuver is an essential life-saving procedure used to relieve airway obstructions in choking individuals by using abdominal thrusts to expel the blockage.
  • ➤ Heimlich maneuver

questions.text: A housewife presents with complaints of a blocked nose, loss of smell, and dry, greenish crusty nasal discharge. On examination, nasal cavities appear roomy and turbinates are atrophied. Which of the following surgeries cannot be done on this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vidian neurectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vidian neurectomy is used for conditions with excessive nasal secretions like vasomotor rhinitis, not atrophic rhinitis, which is characterized by dryness and nasal atrophy.
  • ➤ Vidian neurectomy

questions.text: Gutzmann pressure test is done in a condition where following surgery is indicated
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Shortening thyroplasty

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gutzmann pressure test is used to evaluate whether shortening thyroplasty (Type 3 thyroplasty) is appropriate for patients with puberphonia , a condition where a male has a persistently high-pitched voice.
  • ➤ Gutzmann pressure test
  • ➤ shortening thyroplasty
  • ➤ puberphonia

questions.text: Identify the image. Which is false regarding the condition with this finding?

options.label: B
options.text: High grades of fever may be seen

options.label: C
options.text: Patient should be kept in supine position for better breathing

questions.correct_answer: C. Patient should be kept in supine position for better breathing
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Patient should be kept in supine position for better breathing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute epiglottitis , patients should not be placed in a supine position as it can worsen airway obstruction. Instead, they should be allowed to sit in a tripod position to keep the airway as open as possible. Systemic antibiotics are essential to treat the bacterial infection.
  • ➤ acute epiglottitis
  • ➤ supine position
  • ➤ tripod position
  • ➤ Systemic antibiotics

questions.text: If the vocal cord is found fixed in a case of laryngeal carcinoma, what is the stage of carcinoma then?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In laryngeal carcinoma , the fixation of the vocal cord is a hallmark of T3 staging, corresponding to stage 3 carcinoma in the overall classification system. This is an important feature to remember in evaluating the progression of the disease.
  • ➤ laryngeal carcinoma
  • ➤ T3
  • ➤ stage 3 carcinoma

questions.text: Best method of voice rehabilitation after total laryngectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tracheo oesophageal prosthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheo-oesophageal prosthesis is considered the best method for voice rehabilitation following total laryngectomy due to the superior quality of speech it provides, as it allows for more natural vocalization compared to other methods.
  • ➤ Tracheo-oesophageal prosthesis
  • ➤ best method

questions.text: The image below shows a procedure that was done in the patient. What is the procedure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Needle cricothyroidotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Needle cricothyroidotomy is a rapid, life-saving procedure performed in emergencies when a secure airway is not otherwise obtainable. It provides temporary airway access through the cricothyroid membrane until definitive airway management can be established.
  • ➤ Needle cricothyroidotomy

questions.text: A 7-year-old child post-tonsillectomy comes to you with complaints of snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing and a slight decrease in hearing. On examination, you notice a high arched palate. His school performance has deteriorating as well. His mother is worried. What is the next line of management for this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate management of chronic adenoid hypertrophy with associated complications like otitis media with effusion and obstructive sleep apnea involves adenoidectomy and grommet insertion to alleviate nasal obstruction, improve hearing, and prevent further complications.
  • ➤ chronic adenoid hypertrophy
  • ➤ otitis media with effusion
  • ➤ obstructive sleep apnea
  • ➤ adenoidectomy
  • ➤ grommet insertion

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year. Transnasal endoscopic results are shown below. A contrast-enhanced CT revealed a mass extending from the posterior choana to the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males, presenting with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis. It is crucial to avoid biopsy due to the risk of severe bleeding, and management typically involves imaging (CT or MRI) followed by surgical excision.
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

questions.text: Which of the following is part of trotter's triad, seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss, Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

options.label: C
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive hearing loss, Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

questions.correct_answer: A. Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trotter’s triad in nasopharyngeal carcinoma includes conductive hearing loss , ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia , and palatal paralysis . This triad arises due to tumor invasion of nearby structures, particularly the Eustachian tube, trigeminal nerve, and vagus nerve.
  • ➤ Trotter’s triad
  • ➤ conductive hearing loss
  • ➤ ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia
  • ➤ palatal paralysis
